Edward de Vere.Action: Shows disdain for the theater audience including 'bricklayers and whores' and expresses disinterest in the performance despite Southampton's enthusiasm.
Engages in conversation with Southampton and pauses before entering, showing some measure of openness to the new experience.
Realizes he should stay silent during Essex's conversation about political intrigue, showing discretion.
Leaves quietly without alerting Essex and Southampton to his presence, possibly withholding support.
Reaches out and touches Southampton's shoulder when they exit Essex's house, a gesture of reassurance or connection.
Defends the acceptance of a play as a gift to the queen, standing up to Robert Cecil's harsh judgment and advocating for the queen's choice.
Bows deeply to Young Elizabeth upon her entrance.
Responds politely and sincerely to Young Elizabeth's questions and requests, demonstrating respect and humility.
Shows eagerness to serve Young Elizabeth loyally in both war and state, expressing sincere devotion and trustworthiness.
Smells a rose with appreciation, engages politely with Jonson, and uses influence to secure Jonson's release from jail.
References his powerful and intimidating father-in-law to assert authority, causing Jonson to feel uncomfortable and worried.
Glances at his wife Anne and appears to show some regard for her presence though she watches suspiciously.
Speaks Latin fluently and confidently, offering to assist in translation of ancient Latin texts.
Excels at fencing, outperforming a tutor twice his age and executes a fierce, skillful attack.
Engages in playful but confident banter with Boy Robert Cecil, showing social ease and assuredness.
No direct action or statement recorded in this excerpt; he is mentioned indirectly as Essex.
Protects his poems passionately, insisting they are his soul.
Disobeys orders from William Cecil, causing conflict and concern.
Shows emotional depth and personal conviction through his defense of his work.
Involvement suggests complexity in personal relationships affecting others (William Cecil and daughter).

Refuses Southampton's request for blessing to go to battle, showing reluctance or lack of support.
Appears angry and dismissive toward Jonson, sharply questions him for presuming to speak on his behalf.
Acknowledges Jonson's discretion in keeping his name from Shakespeare, then expresses trust by believing Jonson will continue to do so.
Offers a romantic tragedy manuscript to Jonson, showing pride in his work.
Ignores Anne's concerns about their daughter's dowry and family financial troubles, focusing instead on his writing.
Responds with a deflective historical reference ('Nero fiddled whilst Rome burned') instead of addressing family crisis directly.

Engages Young Elizabeth with intense, meaningful conversation and maintains confidence in social interaction.
Follows Elizabeth into a risky, potentially compromising situation by riding off into the fog unaccompanied.
Engages in intimate, playful, and tender interaction with Young Elizabeth, showing affection and attentiveness.
Makes candid, somewhat bold comments about women in Italy, appreciating their directness.

Offers to personally meet Shakespeare and eventually agrees to pay him a substantial sum despite initial sharpness.
Initially responds sharply and almost ejects Shakespeare, showing impatience and a stern demeanor.
Pays Francesco promptly when asked despite potential danger.
Reflects with melancholy on being abandoned by the Queen and appears emotionally affected.
Remains silent and deep in thought after Bessie tries to advise him about the Queen's feelings.
Turns devastated upon hearing that Essex and his son will be executed for treason.

Expresses disbelief and rejects the claim by saying 'You lie...'
Patiently waits while Elizabeth has a coughing fit, showing calmness and care.
Makes a pact to keep the child's existence a secret to protect him, promising silence.
Expresses desire for unity and peace for the island and people despite personal sacrifice.
Shows disgust toward the Scotsman who will become king, indicating intolerance.
Stands as a statue, devoid of emotion, at the funeral procession of the queen, showing composure in a solemn public event.
Is absent from the crowning ceremony of James I, despite his wife's presence there, indicating a significant omission at a critical political moment.
Graciously invites Jonson to sit by his bedside despite his own illness and vulnerability.
Shares personal family history and expresses regret about his lack of glorious deeds and legacy.
Politely requests silence to speak with Jonson privately, showing respect and control over the situation.
Acknowledges the loneliness of artistic creation and longs for a single person's genuine applause, demonstrating vulnerability and sincerity.
Confides in Jonson to keep the secret of Shakespeare’s true authorship and entrusts him with his manuscripts, showing trust and a willingness to share intimate burdens.
Recognizes Jonson’s flaws yet expresses confidence that Jonson will not betray his words, indicating tolerance and pragmatic trust.
Frowns slightly and shows evident disinterest or disdain at the new theater and its popular audience.
Asks if there will be puppets, indicating skepticism or critical thinking about the quality of the performance.
Observes carefully as he is taken inside, suggesting attentiveness and situational awareness.

Demonstrates intellectual curiosity and cultural knowledge by recognizing and correctly referencing 'deus ex machina' and classical Greek theatre examples.
Becomes intrigued and attentive to the theater environment despite initial reluctance, indicating openness and perceptiveness.

Sits quietly among other nobles and does not participate in Shakespeare's public mocking or social activities at the theater.

Is described as a recluse and less active as a patron or creator, possibly due to a falling out with the Queen, showing withdrawal and reduced influence.

Is indirectly mocked by Shakespeare's character on stage as a fool, indicating that contemporaries may view him as lacking wit or understanding; however, this is more reflective of public perception than direct incompetence.
Watches the nobleman with the big feathered hat pass by without reacting visibly.
Observes the tennis match quietly, correcting Essex with factual input without mockery or sarcasm.
Calls Essex 'naïve' with a smile, lightly mocking his preference for the sword over words.
Chooses not to reveal his presence and remains silent during Essex and Southampton's conversation about political succession and potential conflict.

Touches Southampton's shoulder to warn him discreetly about the Cecils brooking no rivals.

Does not react negatively or show signs of insecurity when faced with opposition or skepticism from William Cecil.
Successfully secures Ben Jonson's freedom by leveraging his father-in-law's authority and writing to Jonson's jailers.
Demonstrates confident social navigation by engaging in conversation with Jonson and managing delicate family/political relations involving Lord William Cecil and his wife Anne.

Displays awareness of potential dangers or tensions, indicated by Jonson's worried look back at Anne after Oxford mentions his intervention, showing Oxford's understanding of complex social/political dynamics.
Writes to Jonson's jailers using his father-in-law's name to secure Jonson's release.
Encourages Jonson by praising his potential and giving him a play to stage under Jonson's own name.
Dismisses official sanction for Jonson's release with some harsh language ('Don't be an idiot Jonson').
Refuses to attach his own name to plays, suggesting a divide between social classes and reputations, implying elitism.
Offers Jonson a chance to put his name on the plays and become financially successful, though with conditions.

Picks a path but chooses the wrong one.

Challenges Boy Robert Cecil's assertion by contradicting him in a competitive but friendly way during chess and fencing.

Half horrified by his own violent action but still maintains presence of mind after stabbing the intruder.
